insist.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to say firmly and often that something is true, especially when other people think it may not be true
insist.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Mike insisted that he was right.
His friends insisted he had no connection with drugs.
She kept insisting on her innocence.
insist.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to demand that something should happen
insist.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: They insisted that everyone should come to the party.
He insisted I should take a taxi.
We insist on the highest standards of cleanliness in the hotel.
He insisted upon checking everything himself.
insist.translation[0].note_box[0].items[: She insists on her own bedroom
She insists on having her own bedroom
In everyday English, you insist that someone does something
In formal English, you insist that someone do something, using the base form of the verb  (=infinitive without ‘to’)
You use the base form of the verb when talking about the past  In everyday English, people also say
You insist that someone should do something  This pattern is often used in the past, when reporting what someone has insisted
They insisted that I should join them
insist.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: to say firmly that someone should do something or that something should happen
She insisted that it was her turn to drive.
to say very strongly and sometimes angrily that you want something or that something must happen
I wrote a letter to the company, demanding an apology and a refund.
The guards demanded to see her ID.
if you are required to do something, a rule or law says that you must do it
The successful applicant will be required to sign a two-year contract.
to say very firmly that something must happen or is right, and refuse to change your mind when other people try to persuade you
The actress has always been adamant about keeping her private life private.
won’t take no for an answer
to insist that someone must do what you say or ask
You’re coming home with me – I won’t take no for an answer.
to say very firmly that someone must not do something
Ed was talking about dropping out of school, but Mom and Dad put their foot down.
